terms.definition: A centralized web-based platform that provides access to documentation, guides, and information resources for users or customers
HTML, CSS, or JavaScript code that can be inserted into a webpage to display content or functionality from another application
A piece of code that automates the process of installing, configuring, and launching an application or service on a web server
A free, open-source code editor developed by Microsoft that supports multiple programming languages and extensions
HyperText Markup Language - the standard markup language used to create and structure content on web pages
Cascading Style Sheets - a language used to describe the presentation and styling of HTML documents
The process of installing and configuring software on your own servers or infrastructure rather than using a hosted solution
A dedicated website or platform that organizes and presents technical documentation, user guides, and help resources
A customizable documentation platform that allows organizations to create and manage knowledge bases and help centers
A document that defines the visual design standards, CSS rules, and formatting conventions for a website or application
CSS custom properties defined at the document level that can be reused throughout a stylesheet to maintain consistent styling
The web address where an application or service will be accessible after it has been deployed to a server
A web-based platform that serves as a gateway to information, applications, and services for a specific audience
A group of technical professionals responsible for developing, maintaining, and supporting software applications and systems
The fundamental CSS styling rules that define the default appearance and layout of a website or application
